headline: Remove multiple punctuation marks
description: Closing a sentence with multiple punctuation marks gives the reader a negative feeling that you are pressuring them or acting impatient. Keep the tone positive by not overusing them.

headline: Avoid using the conditional
description: The verb ‘would’ can appear unconfident or convey possibility that an action won't happen. To encourage a response and show authority, rephrase without 'would'.

headline: Focus on your reader

headline: Focus on your reader

headline: Avoid the conditional

headline: Ask a clear question
description: Keeping in touch is a great way to build a relationship. To make sure your reader feels the same, ask whether it is also useful for them.

headline: Give specific compliments
description: It's great to be cheerful. The best way to give a compliment is by being as specific as possible, so write exactly what you want to congratulate them for.

headline: Paint a story
description: Rather than telling your reader just to think about it, give examples to paint a precise picture of the positive results they will receive by collaborating with you.

headline: Use the organization's name
description: People love to read their organization's name. Adding it shows your reader that they are not reading just another template message.

headline: Ask a clear question
description: You probably want to sound polite, but this phrase makes you sound unconfident. With a clear question, your reader can give a simple and fast answer.

headline: Avoid 'Maybe'
description: Using 'maybe' gives the reader the option to not do what you are asking them. It's better to remove 'maybe'.

headline: Ask a clear question
description: This is a generic phrase your reader will have read many times before. It indirectly gives the impression that you know what they want – you don't. Instead, ask what is important to them.

headline: Avoid 'Discuss'
description: How well do you know your reader? If this is your first contact, take it slow. Suggesting a discussion early in a conversation can come across too pushy. Instead, ask them if the topic is on their mind.

headline: Focus on your reader's organization
description: It's great to mention existing clients to showcase your value. When you do, make sure you name clients that are comparable to your reader's organization. They look for familiarities either in size or industry.

headline: Avoid 'Stress'
description: You are probably trying to empathize with your reader or describe something that's not easy for you. However, negative words will subconsciously affect your reader. Avoid them where possible.

headline: Focus opening on reader
description: Beginning your email with a sentence about yourself or your organization will sound like just another sales pitch. Focus the first sentence on your reader – ideally, write about something they are excited about.

headline: Use your reader's name
description: When communicating, your reader's name is holy. People love to read their own name – use it wherever you can. If you don't know your reader's name, do your research before sending a message.

headline: Avoid exclamation points
description: You are probably using an exclamation point to show excitement. That's a great motive, but exclamation points give the reader a negative feeling that you are pressuring them or impatient.

headline: Avoid multiple punctuation marks
description: Multiple punctuation marks can easily be misinterpreted and cause your message to be misunderstood. Avoid them to keep your message simple.

headline: Avoid 'Worry'
description: Even though you want to say something positive, 'worry' will evoke negative images in your reader's mind. Use more positive words.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: You want to create (some) sense of urgency, so be more specific with your call-to-action (CTA). The best way to ask for something is by asking a direct question with two options your reader can pick from. The second option must be your preferred one.

headline: Keep it to the point
description: Keep it simple by leaving out any words that don't bring value to your message. This way, you make it easier for your reader to see what your request is about.

headline: Avoid the conditional
description: The verb ‘could’ can appear unconfident or convey possibility that an action won't happen. To encourage a response and show authority, rephrase without 'could'.

headline: Avoid the conditional
description: The verb ‘should’ can appear unconfident or convey possibility that an action won't happen. To encourage a response and show authority, rephrase without 'should'.

headline: Take it slow
description: How well do you know your reader? If this is your first contact, take it slow. Suggesting a meeting early in a conversation can come across too pushy. Instead, ask them if the topic is on their mind.

headline: Avoid repeated words
description: If your chosen word needs to be repeated to convey the content, it might not be the right choice. Keep it professional and clean by avoiding repeated words.

headline: Avoid asking early questions
description: It seems like you've asked your reader an important question. Can you move it to the end of the message? This will make the reader more aware of it so they will answer it directly in their response.

headline: Avoid 'No'
description: The word 'no' has negative connotations and will give your reader a bad impression of the interaction. When correcting someone or disagreeing, remove 'no'.

headline: Avoid correcting your reader
description: Don't tell someone they are wrong, as this will give them a negative impression of the interaction. Instead of pointing out their mistake, simply tell them what is correct.

headline: Lower the pressure
description: Using 'need' to ask someone to complete a task for you sounds as if they're at your disposal and you don't value their time. Phrase the sentence more politely to create a positive impression.

headline: Write out 'Thank you'
description: Take the time to write out 'thank you' in full rather than 'thanks' to show your reader you care about them and respect their time.

headline: Avoid 'Sorry'
description: Are you really sorry? If the situation is beyond your control, you don't need to apologize. It will only create a negative atmosphere.

headline: Show confidence
description: Using 'just' in a sentence softens the effect of what you're saying and makes it look like you are meek or unsure. It's better to remove 'just' to show authority. When used to refer to time, 'just' is an unnecessary addition which can be removed for succinctness.

headline: Avoid 'Kind of'
description: Kind of' conveys the impression that you are meek or unsure. Remove 'kind of' to sound more authoritative.

headline: Show confidence
description: Hopefully' gives your reader the impression that the action might not happen. Remove ‘hopefully’ to sound more authoritative. Give assurance to your reader about the outcome of the action.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Statistically' is an unnecessary word. If you're citing a statistic, 'statistically' is implied.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: So' is a filler word which wastes space and makes your readers lose interest in your message as their attention dwindles. Remove 'so'.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: As you know' is a redundant phrase. If the reader already knows it, why waste their time repeating it? If the point you're making really needs to be repeated, use 'since' or 'because' rather than 'as you know'.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Have you written 'basically' to be concise and to-the-point? In that case, it is more concise to simply remove 'basically'.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Pretty much' is a filler phrase which can be removed to save your reader's time spent reading the message. If it can't, replace it with 'almost' or 'usually' which sound more professional.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Surely you are writing the message to the person it concerns. For that reason, 'to whom it may concern' is redundant and you should remove it.

headline: Take it slow
description: How well do you know your reader? If this is your first contact, take it slow. Suggesting a meeting early in a conversation can come across as being pushy. Rather ask them if the topic is on their mind. If you have already developed a relationship with them, it is okay to suggest a meeting.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: People use this phrase to sound more eloquent. However, it will use your reader's time and make them impatient with your message. Remove it to make the message more direct.

headline: Avoid modal 'Can'
description: Can' expresses possibility and unsurety. Remove it as it suggests that the outcome may not be achieved. Grab your reader's attention by using 'you' to show how they will benefit and use an affirmative verb to ensure them this will be achieved.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: In particular' is a filler phrase which is not effective in conveying a clear message. Remove it to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Herewith' is a word people use to sound more eloquent. However, it is going to use your reader's time and make them more impatient with your message. Remove it to make the message more direct.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Of course' is a phrase which is not effective in conveying clear messages. Remove it to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Literally' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove it to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Really' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘really’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Already' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘already’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Currently' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘currently’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Right now' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘right now’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Especially' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘especially’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: At the moment' is a filler phrase which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘at the moment’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: As it stands' is a filler phrase which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘as it stands’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Adverbs take up space in your message and don't convey much meaning. Remove them where possible so your reader gets a shorter message which they are more likely to read.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Additionally' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘additionally’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Unfortunately' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘unfortunately’ to ensure your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: As you might have seen' is a filler phrase which will use up more of your reader's time and make them impatient. Why would they have seen it? Remove it to be more succinct.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: At least' is a filler phrase which will use up your reader's time. It also includes a negative word, 'least' that can create a negative impression of the interaction. Remove it to be more succinct and positive.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Actually' is a filler word which will use up more of your reader's time and make them impatient. Remove 'actually' to be more succinct.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: This phrase is often repeated in emails but takes up time from your reader's limited attention span. The shorter the message the better.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Definitely' is a filler word which will use more of your reader's time and make them impatient. Remove 'definitely' to be more direct.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Thus' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘thus’ to make your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Generally' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘generally’ to make your ideas sound clear and confident.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: As you may know' is a filler phrase which will use more of your reader's time and make them impatient. Why would they know? Remove it to be more direct.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: As you may have noticed' is a filler phrase which will use more of your reader's time and make them impatient. Why would they have noticed? Remove it to be more direct.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: As you may have seen' is a filler phrase which will use more of your reader's time and make them impatient. Why would they have seen it? Remove it to be more direct.

headline: Use positive words
description: Expenses' will evoke negative imagery in your reader's mind, regardless of context. Phrase it another way to keep the tone positive.

headline: Use positive words
description: Costs' will evoke negative imagery in your reader's mind, regardless of context. Phrase it another way to keep the tone positive.

headline: Use positive words
description: Risk' will evoke negative imagery in your reader's mind, regardless of context. Phrase it another way to keep the tone positive.

headline: Use positive words
description: You are probably using this word to sympathize with your reader. Rather than focusing on the negative, highlight how this will be resolved.

headline: Avoid 'Still'
description: Still' conveys impatience because something hasn't been completed or achieved, or you're awaiting a reply. Remove 'still' to give the reader a positive impression of the interaction.

headline: Show you're in control
description: Suppose' suggests to the reader that you don't have belief, confidence or enthusiasm in the interaction. Remove it to give a positive impression.

headline: Show you're in control
description: I thought' suggests to the reader that you don't have belief, confidence or enthusiasm in the interaction. Remove it to give a positive impression.

headline: Avoid 'Happy to'
description: Telling your reader you are 'happy to' do something is not a direct way to find out whether they are interested or this will benefit them. Rephrase the sentence more directly without 'happy to' to invite their response.

headline: Avoid 'Happy to'
description: Telling your reader you are 'happy to' do something is not a direct way to find out whether they are interested. Ask a question to invite their response.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: To create urgency you need to be more specific with your call-to-action (CTA). The best way to invite a response is asking an OR question with two options. The second option must be your preferred one.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: To create urgency you need to be more specific with your call-to-action (CTA). The best way to invite a response is asking an OR question with two options. The second option must be your preferred one.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: How's your availability' is not a direct way to ask someone if they will be available. Form a direct question, starting with 'do', to encourage a response to your call-to-action (CTA).

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: This is a stock phrase that your reader will have read multiple times before. If you've organized a time to talk, close by reminding them of the date and time you will speak. If not, ask an OR question to invite them to pick a time when you can talk.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: To create urgency you need to be more specific with your call-to-action (CTA). The best way to invite a response is asking an OR question with two options. The second option must be your preferred one.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: If your reader can't make the proposed time, they may not respond. Ask an OR question to encourage them to pick the time which is the better for them. The second one must be your preferred option.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: To create urgency you need to be more specific with your call-to-action (CTA). The best way to invite a response is asking an OR question with two options. The second option must be your preferred one.

headline: Avoid the conditional
description: The verb 'would' makes you seem unsure whether the reader will be interested. By removing 'would', it will be easier to convince your reader as you are showing them you are confident.

headline: Avoid the conditional
description: The verb 'could' makes you seem unsure whether the reader will be interested. By removing 'could' and asking your reader a direct question using 'you', they will feel more motivated to take action.

headline: Avoid the conditional
description: The verb 'would' makes you seem unsure whether the reader will be interested. By removing 'would' and asking your reader a direct question using 'you', they will feel more motivated to take action.

headline: Avoid the conditional
description: May', 'might' and 'shall' belong to a group of verbs which can show hesitancy and uncertainty. In place of these verbs, make statements and explain why they're true.

headline: Avoid 'In case'
description: In case' shows uncertainty that something will happen. Remove it to sound more confident.

headline: Avoid 'No' and 'Not'
description: Avoid putting your sentences into the negative by using 'no' and 'not', as this leaves a negative impression on your reader. Tell them what you are, not what you're not.

headline: Avoid 'Not only'
description: Avoid putting your sentences into the negative by using 'not'. 'Not only' has to be followed with 'but', suggesting conflict; this will leave a negative impression on your reader.

headline: Avoid 'No'
description: You've used this term to say something positive, but the 'no' will leave a negative impression on your reader. Rephrase it to sound positive.

headline: Avoid sounding negative
description: Avoid putting your sentences into the negative by using 'not' or saying 'against'. This will leave a negative impression on your reader.

headline: Avoid 'Non-binding'
description: You've used this term to say something positive, but 'non-binding' will leave a negative impression on your reader. Rephrase it to sound positive.

headline: Be to the point
description: If you need to 'sum it up' or 'recap', your message is probably too long and complex. You don't need to give every detail.

headline: Be to the point
description: Anything that follows after 'I was hoping' is redundant – it hasn't been achieved yet. Focus on the reality to sound clear and confident.

headline: Show you're in control
description: This phrase makes it sound like you don't care about the outcome and it's out of your control. To show confidence and authority, remove it.

headline: Show you're in control
description: This phrase makes it sound like you don't care about the outcome and it's out of your control. To show confidence and authority, remove it.

headline: Show you're in control
description: This phrase makes it sound like you don't care about the outcome and it's out of your control. To show confidence and authority, remove it.

headline: Focus on your reader's benefit
description: We/I wanted to help you' is an insincere way to talk about what you want. Ask yourself what your reader wants and then highlight how they will benefit from talking to you.

headline: Show you're in control
description: Rather than leaving the progression of the interaction to your reader, make a clear call-to-action with an OR question to invite their reply and show you're in control.

headline: Be precise
description: This word is imprecise and used often in outreach messages. Explain more clearly what the product does.

headline: Don't overuse 'Please'
description: Though you are trying to sound polite, don't overuse 'please'. You will sound pushy and discourage your reader. Only use it when you are asking for something extraordinary.

headline: Focus on your reader
description: Rather than phrasing your message from your viewpoint, change 'I' or 'we' pronouns to 'you', so your reader can more easily visualize themselves in the scenario and understand what they are going to gain from the interaction with you.

headline: Focus on who is doing the action
description: The passive voice detracts from your writing because it makes it unclear who or what is doing the action. Make the action and actor of the sentence clear to your reader.

headline: Avoid filler words
description: Hence' is a filler word which is not effective in conveying messages. Remove ‘hence’ to make your ideas clearer.

headline: Show you're in control
description: Figured' suggests to the reader that you don't have belief, confidence or enthusiasm in the interaction. Remove it to sound more confident.

headline: Make a clear call-to-action
description: To create urgency you need to be more specific with your call-to-action (CTA). The best way to invite a response is asking an OR question with two options. The second option must be your preferred one.

headline: Thank the reader
description: Closing expressions that convey gratitude, such as 'Thank you' and 'Thanks' have the highest response rate (around 36% relative increase) compared to other closing notes. Always sign off your emails by expressing your gratitude to the reader.

headline: Avoid overused terms
description: Phrases such as these are very common openers in sales messages. They are likely to turn your reader off, as they'll think this is a message like all other sales messages and you're likely to be wasting their time. Try to entirely omit it or rephrase if necessary.
